sect2.title: Export selected

row.entry: Each workflow ends in this panel: the export of your developed images. You can export either to a file on disk, or to various on-line storage places. Tip: you can use ctrl-e from within darkroom mode to export.

sect2.para: All settings of this panel can be saved for later reuse. Press the button to manage your presets.

sect4.title: target storage
sect4.para: Where to store your selected images. Different back-ends are implemented, including file on disk, a LaTeX book template and various web albums. Depending on the selected target, you will be asked to give additional information, like filenames, or account name and password.

sect4.title: filename template
sect4.para: You can define filenames that darktable generates for export. Several pre-defined variables can be used as placeholders:

row.entry: a sequence number within export job

sect4.title: output directory
sect4.para: Pressing button opens a dialog to select the parent directory for export.

sect4.title: file format
sect4.para: darktable can export to various file formats. For some of them you need to define the desired bit depth of the exported image. If you export to a JPEG file you can define an output quality. Higher values will lead to larger file sizes.

If the file format supports embedded metadata, like JPEG, JPEG2000 and TIFF, darktable will try to store the history stack as XMP tags within the output file. This information can later be used to reconstruct your parameters and settings that have produced the exported image (see ).

para.emphasis: Caution: for various reasons embedding XMP tags into output files may fail without notice. Users are therefore advised to not rely their backup strategy on this feature.

sect4.para:
If you don't want to distribute history stack data with your images, there are various tools to delete embedded XMP tags. As an example you can use the program exiftool with:
exiftool -XMP:all= image.jpg

sect4.title: max size
sect4.para: Set the maximum width and height of the output images in pixels. Set both to a value of "0" to export with full resolution. darktable currently can only do down-scaling; the maximum output resolution is defined by the parent image.

para.emphasis: Caution: it's a frequent pitfall to accidentally put low values, like 1 or 10, in these fields, causing darktable to produce miniature output files. You might think darktable's output is broken, but in fact it only generated what you asked for.

sect4.title: intent
sect4.para: This option lets you define the intent, i.e. the way darktable will deal with out-of-gamut colors. See for a more detailed description of the available options.

sect4.title: profile
sect4.para: This defines the output color profile. Select image settings if you want the settings in the output color profile (see ) module of the individual images to take precedence.

sect4.title: style
sect4.para: This option lets you choose a style, i.e. a collection of history stack items, which darktable concatenates with the existing history stack to generate the output image. These history items are only added temporarily; the original history stack is not overwritten. You can use this feature to add processing steps and parameters that you want to be applied specifically to exported images, e.g. you may define a style that adds a stronger level of sharpening when you produce scaled-down JPEG files for the internet. Learn more about styles in , and .

sect4.title: export
sect4.para: Pressing this button starts a background job to export all selected images. A bar at the bottom of the left side panel displays the progress. Whenever a file is successfully exported, a notification message pops up for a few seconds. You may click on the pop-up to make it disappear.
